{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3427140,"name":"shannon","username":"shanoon","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/85e7bf/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-09-25T15:49:02.222Z","cooked":"

We’re currently resurfacing our CNC router’s MDF, which we’ve done once or twice before, but this time, there’s a lot more MDF dust in the air to the point that everyone around the machine was covered in dust. I was wondering if anyone has safety measures (N95 masks, etc) or suggestions for how to improve the facing process.

I just run a very good vacuum mounted to a 3d printed dust boot on the spindle. My shop vac accepts HEPA filters. Haven’t really had any issues. If you want additional air filtration there’s plenty of ceiling mountable options available. Unsure how good this one is but its pretty affordable - Wen Air Filter

Would you need to take the dust boot off towards the edges of the machine?

When resurfacing - yes, but even still, I feel safe enough with my router to just hold a vacuum up to it when the dust boot isn’t on.

N95’s are still a good idea though. I think you’re likely making the right choices here for safety.

looks back at the shear amout of dust and chips at a previous job I had

Having said that I am sure there was substantially more space at said previous job so we could get away with more, even if it wasn’t as safe in absolute terms.

Typically our operators will mask up for longer jobs like resurfacing.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2024-09-25T16:47:28.895Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":124,"readers_count":123,"score":39.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":471875,"topic_slug":"mdf-dust-concerns","display_username":"s-neff","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28019,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/mdf-dust-concerns/471875/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3427307,"name":"Patrick","username":"Patrick3357","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/patrick3357/{size}/169915_2.png","created_at":"2024-09-25T18:36:48.076Z","cooked":"

If you’re noticing dust in the air, you should be wearing masks at a minimum. If this is a once or twice a year event have everyone mask up and clean up the dust so it isn’t repeatedly floated back into the air until it’s filtered by someone’s lungs. If you’re regularly cutting wood of any kind you need good dust collection.
